I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
the Islamic Republic of Pakistan for the Greater Thal Canal Irrigation Project.  
 
2.  The project will contribute to enhancing food security and rural economic growth in Punjab 
province. It will increase the agricultural production and productivity of the project area by 
developing a new irrigation system. The Greater Thal Canal (GTC) irrigation scheme will convert 
704,000 hectares (ha) of low productive barani (rain-fed) lands in Bhakkar, Jhang, Muzaffargarh, 
Khushab, and Layyah districts of Punjab to irrigated and productive lands. It will provide reliable 
irrigation water supplies during the monsoon kharif (monsoon) season from April to September. 
The government has constructed the Main Canal and first branch (Mankera) system.1 The project 
will support (i) construction of the irrigation canal network in the second branch (Choubara) 
system; and (ii) on-farm command area development (CAD) in the Main Canal, Mankera branch 
and Choubara branch areas covering about 263,000 ha of irrigable command areas. The project 
will also enhance the capacity of relevant government entities and water users for (i) efficient 
water management, (ii) introduction of advanced technologies, (iii) improved and climate-resilient 
agricultural practices, and (iv) sustainable infrastructure.  
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  The economy and food security. The agriculture sector generates jobs and earns 
significant export revenues for Pakistan. Agriculture’s share in the country’s gross domestic 
product declined from 29.0% in 1985 to 18.7% in the fiscal year (FY) 2019.2 Despite this trend, 
the sector absorbs 39% of the country’s total labor force3 and 45% in Punjab province.4 About 
80% of national exports originate from the agriculture sector and Punjab province contributes a 
60% share in national exports.5 In FY2017, the province produced 76.7% of the nation’s total 
production of wheat, 50.7% of rice, 65.7% of sugarcane, 85.4% of maize, and 65.4% of cotton.6 
Punjab’s agriculture sector is also the main source of food production for the country’s increasing 
population which has an annual growth rate of about 2%.7 In Pakistan, 60% of the population 
experience food insecurity, and about 22% of the population is undernourished. Food supply in 
the country is still lower than the demand. About 44% of overall household incomes, and 48% of 
the rural population’s incomes are spent on food. Addressing malnutrition requires increased 
affordable food supply.8 Developing new agricultural lands and increasing agriculture productivity 
are critical for the food security of the increasing population, and also for the province’s economic 
growth and livelihood, particularly in rural areas. This has particularly become important under

economic uncertainties of the country that were seriously affected by the coronavirus disease

4.  Rural poverty. About 26% of Punjab province’s population lives below the poverty line.9 
Poverty incidence in the project area is significantly higher than the provincial average and ranges 
from 64.8% in Muzaffargarh district, 51.7% in Bhakkar district, and 40.4% in Khushab district in 
FY2015.10 Farm-based economic activities contribute 40% of rural households’ income. Poverty 
in Pakistan is estimated to have increased from 24.3% to 44.2% because of the COVID-19 
pandemic.11 
 
5.  Sector challenges.  Because of Pakistan’s semi-arid climate, it is highly dependent on 
irrigation for agricultural production. The Indus Basin Irrigation System (IBIS) services 14.9 million 
ha out of a total 22.04 million ha of cultivated land in Pakistan.12 Farming in areas outside of the 
IBIS relies on rainfall or groundwater. Groundwater tables tend to be low in non-irrigated areas, 
and pumping requires high costs. Therefore, groundwater irrigation is not prominent in such 
areas. Although Punjab province accounts for more than 70% of the cropped area of the IBIS, 
13.3% of cultivable land in Punjab remains rain-fed.13 Some of the country’s poorest populations 
also reside in these barani (rain-fed) areas and are dependent on agriculture as a major source 
of income. Without a secure and reliable irrigation water supply, agricultural production in the 
barani areas is both a low-productivity and a high-risk venture. It contributes to low farm incomes 
and slow agricultural growth. 
 
6.  Although Pakistan is water scarce, the crop water requirements in irrigation systems have 
increased because of rising cropping intensities and application of high water-consuming crops. 
Irrigation efficiency is low at about 40%.14 Agriculture productivity per unit of water is below global 
and regional averages because of water shortages, land degradation, and mismanagement of 
water resources.15 The IBIS is also encountering financial challenges, recovering only 24% of 
operation and maintenance (O&M) costs.16 To address this challenge, the Government of Punjab 
in 2019 increased the abiana (irrigation service fee) from $0.76 per ha (PRs50 per acre) to $1.71 
per ha (PRs110 per acre) for rabi (winter) crops and $1.32 per ha (PRs85 per acre) to $2.63 per 
ha (PRs170 per acre) for kharif (summer) crops. The government has been exploring further 
increase of abiana.  
 
7.  Climate change impacts. Pakistan was ranked fifth among the 181 countries most 
affected by adverse impacts of climate change during 1999–2018.17 Likely impacts include 
greater unpredictability in monsoons and rainfall, leading to more frequent and intense floods or

8.  Women’s role in agriculture. About three-quarters of women and girls in the labor force 
in Pakistan work in the agriculture sector.19 This is mainly in dairy and livestock, with only “19% 
of them in paid employment and 60% as unpaid workers in family farms and enterprises.”20 In 
Punjab in 2018, 66% of women in the labor force were in the agriculture sector compared to 29% 
of men.21 Although women in Pakistan have statutory rights to own land, customary practices limit 
their access to land. Only 1%–2% of women individually own land and about 10% have joint 
ownership with their spouses (but with little effective control over land).22 Poor access to land and 
limited  engagement  in  economic  activities  are  detrimental  to  rural  women’s  agricultural 
productivity.  They  restrict  their  access  to  agricultural  services  like  processing  and  storage 
facilities,  capacity  development  and  skills  training,  agricultural  inputs,  and  benefits  from 
participation in water users associations (WUAs) (footnote 20).     
 
9.  COVID-19 impacts. The outbreak of COVID-19 had significant negative impacts on the 
country’s economy. Inflation surged from 6.8% in FY2019 to 11.5% in FY2020, led by food price 
inflation, which averaged 13.6% in urban areas and 15.9% in rural areas.23  Principally wheat and 
wheat flour prices were forced up by international and inter-provincial supply chain disruptions. 
Food insecurity increased, especially for the poor. This highlights the importance of locally 
sourced food to which the project will contribute. It will also support post-COVID-19 pandemic 
economic recovery in domestic agricultural production. The project will provide employment 
opportunities to the rural population, including returning international and domestic migrants, and 
positively contribute to upstream and downstream industries. Rural income increases could offset 
the impact on families that have depended on overseas remittances.  
 
10.  Development coordination. The federal and provincial governments maintain high-level 
dialogue,  and  oversight  and  monitoring  of  policies  and  development  programs. 24  Major 
development partners in the agriculture and water resources sector are the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB), the Japan International Cooperation Agency, and the World Bank. The recently 
completed and ongoing interventions by the major development partners provide support for 
upgrading, modernizing or constructing irrigation systems and barrages, and CAD. These aim to

government institutions, water users, and communities. Prior development partner interventions 
were largely focused on rehabilitation and/or modernization of existing barrages and irrigation 
systems. For further increase of agricultural production to support food security, development of 
new irrigation systems, such as the GTC scheme is increasingly important. 
 
11.  Strategic context. The project is aligned with the following operational priorities of ADB’s 
Strategy  2030:  (i)  addressing  remaining  poverty  and  reducing  inequalities,  (ii)  accelerating 
progress in gender equality, (iii) building climate-resilience, (iv) promoting rural development and 
food security, and (v) strengthening governance and institutional capacity.25 The project will 
contribute to addressing remaining poverty and reducing inequalities by enhancing the incomes 
of the rural poor, and building climate and disaster resilience. It will enhance environmental 
sustainability by providing reliable irrigation water to a previously rain-fed area, and by introducing 
high efficiency irrigation to minimize water losses. The project directly supports pillar 2 (building 
resilience by strengthening human capital and social protection) of ADB’s country partnership 
strategy  for  Pakistan,  2021–2025  for  strengthening  resilience  of  the  rural  economy  in  the 
aftermath  of the  COVID-19  pandemic,  promoting  climate  change  adaptation,  and reducing 
economic and social vulnerabilities.26 The Government of Punjab’s Medium-Term Development 
Framework,  2020–2023  prioritizes  expanded  and  reliable  irrigation  supplies  and  enhanced 
agricultural productivity (footnote 9). The National Water Policy 2018 indicates the importance of 
O&M, adequate water pricing, the adoption of improved technologies, and extension to new 
command areas.27  
 
12.  The project. The GTC irrigation scheme was partially constructed in 2009. The water 
allocation for the entire GTC was approved by the Indus River System Authority (para. 28).28 The 
scheme’s agricultural potential has not been fully realized because the remaining three branch 
canal systems and their command areas have not been developed. The areas to be covered by 
these branch systems have low productivity and continue to rely on rain-fed or limited ground 
water irrigation. The proposed project will convert the low productive lands in the Main Canal, and 
Mankera and Choubara branch areas into climate-resilient and productive irrigated lands. It is 
designed as the first ADB-financed project of a potentially phased support for sequentially 
completing the development of the entire GTC scheme. Project preparation was supported by 
transaction technical assistance (TA).29  
 
B.  Project Description 
 
13.  The project is aligned with the following impacts: food security enhanced30 and rural 
poverty in Punjab reduced.31 The project will have the following outcome: agricultural production 
and productivity in the project area increased.32

14.  Output 1: Irrigation system infrastructure for Choubara branch system constructed. 
This output will construct irrigation canals and associated structures in the Choubara branch 
system. The major activities will include (i) construction of the Choubara branch system, (ii) tree 
planting along irrigation canals for the Main Canal and Mankera and Choubara branch systems 
as wind breakers to prevent sediment deposits entering the irrigation canals, (iii) desilting of the 
Main Canal and Mankera branch systems, (iv) construction and renovation of operational and 
administration  site  buildings  for  the  Punjab  Irrigation  Department  (PID),  and  (v)  the 
implementation  of  a  social  development  action  plan  to receive  an  increased  population  in 
agricultural labor. The social development action plan includes equipment procurement for a basic 
health unit, upgrading of a girls’ school, and vocational training (para. 37). The Choubara branch 
system includes the construction of 72 kilometers (km) total length of the branch canal, 251 km 
total length of 11 secondary canals, and 127 km total length of 11 tertiary canals. 
 
15.  Output 2: On-farm command area developed with enhanced beneficiaries’ capacity. 
CAD  activities  in  the  Main  Canal,  and  Mankera  and  Choubara  branch  areas  will  include 
(i) development and construction of on-farm watercourses using farmer construction contracts, 
social  mobilization  and  WUA  formation;  (ii)  implementation  of  piloting  for  improved  water 
productivity, such as increased lining of watercourses, land leveling, high efficiency irrigation 
systems (HEISs) including drip irrigation systems, water retention ponds, and piped watercourses; 
(iii) awareness campaign and capacity development of farmers on improved on-farm water 
management and climate-resilient agricultural practices, including extension services like farmer 
field schools and provision of high-yielding seeds; (iv) construction of site buildings for the Punjab 
Agriculture Department (PAD); and (v) capacity development of the PAD including CAD planning 
using a geographic information system (GIS) and satellite data.  
 
16.  Output  3:  Institutional  system  for  irrigation  scheme  and  water  resource 
management  strengthened.  This  output  will  enhance  the  PID’s  institutional  capacity  for 
improved water resources management and O&M of irrigation systems for sustainability. The 
activities will include support for (i) GIS-based asset management system development, (ii) 
installation of groundwater monitoring equipment and development of groundwater modelling for 
the entire GTC area, (iii) implementation of groundwater recharge piloting, (iv) canal flow water 
measurement system installation for monitoring efficient water use, (v) capacity development 
activities for PID staff including long- and short-term training, (vi) GIS-based monitoring and 
evaluation  system  development,  and  (vii)  implementation  of  other  institutional  capacity 
strengthening that will be programmed under ADB’s ongoing capacity development TA for the 
PID.33 These activities may include asset management decision-making system development and 
actions for the implementation of the Punjab Water Act 2019. 
 
17.  Lessons. The project will build on lessons from interventions in the Main Canal and 
Mankera branch areas, and other similar irrigation projects financed by the federal and provincial 
governments, ADB, and other development partners. Since the construction of the Main Canal 
and Mankera branch was completed in 2009, only 25%–30% of its total command area has been 
developed.  A  CAD  component  was  not  included  in  the  Main  Canal  and  Mankera  branch 
construction interventions and investment benefits have yet to be realized. The key technical 
challenges identified for the CAD in the GTC area are as follows: (i) water conveyance and 
application to farms is difficult because of the undulating terrain, and (ii) a 6-month period during 
which there is no water flowing in the irrigation canals could result in channels being buried by 
wind-blown sands. 
 
33  ADB. 2016. Technical Assistance to the Islamic Republic of Pakistan for Institutional Transformation of the Punjab 
Irrigation Department to a Water Resources Department. Manila (TA 9255-PAK).

6 
18.  The major lessons included in the project are: (i) support for on-farm CAD should be 
integrated into infrastructure development; (ii) close coordination between the PID and PAD will 
create an enabling environment; (iii) CAD to be coupled with capacity development of farmers for 
improved and climate-resilient agricultural practices and efficient water use; (iv) awareness 
campaigns, demonstrations and subsidies for high efficiency irrigation and other technologies  to 
be included; (v) water use efficiency and conjunctive use of surface and groundwater to be 
considered  in  CAD  planning;  and  (vi)  on-farm  CAD  to  adopt  a  participatory  and  inclusive 
approach. 
 
C.  Value Added by ADB  
 
19.  The project will integrate infrastructure and agriculture interventions to maximize the 
benefits from irrigated agriculture. From the lessons learnt, the project was designed to allocate 
ample time for CAD activities with beneficiary involvement and capacity strengthening of farmers, 
PAD, and PID even after the completion of major infrastructure works. It will include water users’ 
capacity building in improved and climate-resilient agriculture practices, HEISs (including drip 
irrigation systems), and the application of advance technologies like satellite and GIS-based 
systems. The capacity development of the PAD and the PID will also include the latest best 
practices in irrigated agriculture, digitized water and agricultural data acquisition, efficient water 
use, water management, and infrastructure sustainability. The project will include tree planting 
along the canals to serve as windbreakers and the piloting of the piped watercourses. The 
project’s innovative features, including a focus on high water productivity in dryland areas offers 
an opportunity to showcase value added practices to other barani areas in Pakistan.  
 
20.  The project will introduce advanced technologies including (i) application of satellite data 
for optimizing and planning CAD activities; (ii) utilization of remote sensing technology for efficient 
monitoring and evaluation of project impacts, e.g., cropped area expansion; (iii) piloting of 
groundwater recharge; and (iv) development of a GIS-based asset management, CAD planning, 
and project monitoring and evaluation systems. With support from the project, the PID and the 
PAD will collect reliable data of the project area, such as topography, irrigation water flow 
discharges, and groundwater. Such data will provide background information for future decision-
making  regarding  design  and  investment  scheduling  for  the  remaining  branch  system 
development.  
 
D.  Summary Cost Estimates and Financing Plan 
 
21.  The project is estimated to cost ¥27,979.6 million ($249.3 million equivalent) (Table 1). 
Detailed cost estimates by expenditure category and by financier are included in the project 
administration manual (PAM).34 The major expenditure items include civil works, on-farm CAD 
activity  support,  consulting  services,  institutional  capacity  strengthening,  and  project 
management.

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
28.  The technical viability and economic feasibility for the entire GTC scheme were confirmed 
by the federal government in 2005. These were reconfirmed for the proposed project in 2019–
2021 through the updated detailed design undertaken by a government-financed consultants’ 
team and the ADB-financed transaction TA (footnote 29). Water allocation for the entire GTC 
scheme  was  determined  and  approved  by  the  Indus  River  System  Authority  in  2002  and 
reconfirmed by the authority in 2021. It is within the provincial allocation for the Punjab province, 
as defined under the Water Apportionment Accord.36 The actual water use in Punjab, water 
availability, climate change impacts and downstream flows were assessed under the transaction 
TA. The project will not alter or exceed the approved provincial water allocation and will not impact 
water allocation for downstream areas. The GTC irrigation scheme is non-perennial and will use 
water only during the kharif season from about April to September. The major physical works 
proposed under the project are the construction of irrigation canals and their associated structures, 
such as gated regulators. These are comparatively simple engineering works and the PID has 
substantial prior experience in constructing and operating similar structures. Other technical 
viabilities, including engineering design, drainage needs, soil characteristics, estimated cropping 
patterns and groundwater conditions, were also confirmed through assessments under the 
transaction TA. The findings were included in the project design.37  
 
29.  The project will provide reliable irrigation water supply. It will also improve farmers’ 
capacity for climate-resilient agricultural activities through the on-farm CAD activities. These 
include introduction of water conservation irrigation technologies like HEISs and small water 
retention  ponds,  knowledge  on  efficient  water  uses  under  the  water  scarcity  status,  and 
appropriate crop selection and agricultural practices for climate resilience. Tree planting along the 
irrigation canals will contribute to climate change mitigation (footnote 18). The project will also 
enhance sustainability through (i) beneficiary participation in the construction of on-farm minor 
canals and structures; and (ii) provision of support for the PID’s capacity strengthening for 
improved sustainability of irrigation schemes, including asset database development.  
 
B.  Economic and Financial Viability 
 
30.  Economic and financial analyses indicate that the project is economically viable and 
financially sustainable. The economic internal rate of return for the project is 13%. Benefits of the 
project will be derived from improved agricultural productivity over an area of 263,000 ha, with the 
main factor being the increase in the kharif crop intensities in the Choubara branch area. With the 
provision of reliable irrigation water supply to the existing unirrigated command area, and CAD 
interventions, it is anticipated that there will be (i) a significant improvement in the cropping 
pattern, cropping intensity, and crop yields; and (ii) a shift towards high value crops, with 
significant incremental economic value from melons, dates, sesame seeds, citrus, mung beans

37 Summary of Technical Due Diligence (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

10 
and  onions.  Water  retention  ponds  (to  increase  soil  moisture),  and  gradual  increase  of 
groundwater table will also enable increased and diversified rabi cropping. The sensitivity tests 
and risk analysis confirm that the project is consistently robust. The project remains economically 
viable under all sensitivity test scenarios.  
 
31.  The project will also bring indirect and intangible benefits, such as increased employment 
to landless and seasonal laborers, increased local food production that will provide food security 
to the farming community, increased farmers’ knowledge on improved agricultural practices and 
more efficient water use. Indirect benefits also include increased revenues and employment for 
upstream  (input  supply  companies)  and  downstream  (processing  companies  and  traders) 
industries.  The project will also substantially benefit the rural poor through increased incomes. 
 
32.  The financial sustainability analysis of this nonrevenue-generating project focused on 
assessing the Government of Punjab’s capacity to adequately fund the incremental O&M costs. 
The management and O&M of Punjab’s irrigation systems are estimated at $51.30 per ha per 
year. During 2013–2016, the Government of Punjab allocated $158 million equivalent or $18.60 
per ha annually on average for this purpose. Despite the financial gap, Punjab’s irrigation systems 
are in reasonably good condition and deliver an acceptable level of service to end users. The 
Government of Punjab will allocate adequate resources to fully implement the O&M plan to be 
developed under the project. Ensuring the financial sustainability of irrigation systems is a core 
focus of the PID. ADB, through its capacity development TA, is supporting the sector reforms and 
the implementation of action plans will be supported by the project (footnote 33). 
 
C.  Sustainability 
 
33.  Sustainability measures have been built into the project design. The project will support 
the PID’s implementation of O&M efficiency and sustainability enhancement. These will include 
structural efforts like tree planting to reduce sediment deposition in canals and non-structural 
support for developing an asset management decision-making system. Siltation is one of the 
major challenges for ensuring the sustainability of the structural functions of the GTC irrigation 
infrastructure. The tree planting along the irrigation canals will reduce the PID’s regular O&M 
costs for sediment removal. The project will finance asset inventory and condition assessment. It 
will form the basis for a future asset management decision-making system to systematically 
prioritize and strategically plan O&M activities.38 The PID has also initiated improvement of 
irrigation services cost recovery. This includes updating the abiana (irrigation service fee) rate 
and digitizing abiana collection. The asset management decision-making system and improved 
irrigation services cost recovery will complement each other for ensuing sustainability of the 
irrigation structures and irrigation water supply.   
 
D.  Governance 
 
34.  The assessed pre-mitigation financial management risk for the PID and the PAD is 
substantial, mainly because of (i) the absence of an independent internal audit system and (ii) the 
use of a manual accounting system. The financial management systems of the PID and the PAD 
have improved through the implementation of recent and ongoing projects financed by ADB and 
the World Bank. While the existing financial management staff and systems are appropriate to 
implement the project, residual financial management risks remain. The project procurement risk 
is rated medium. The PID and the PAD have demonstrated satisfactory procurement performance

35.  The project completion report of ADB’s Punjab Irrigated Agriculture Investment Program

that the PID demonstrated competence in procurement, financial management, safeguards and 
other project management matters to meet ADB’s requirements. The project sets clear input and 
output targets to promote good governance. Risk mitigation measures have been identified and 
incorporated in the project design and risk management plan (para. 45). 
 
36.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the government, the PID, and the PAD. The specific policy requirements and supplementary

E.  Poverty, Social, and Gender 
 
37.  The project will have direct positive impacts on poverty reduction and food security among 
the rural poor. The direct beneficiaries of the project will be smallholder farmers. The Main Canal 
and Mankera branch areas are estimated to have 49,000 farmer households with an average 
farm size of 3.1 ha. In the Choubara branch areas, there are about 38,000 farmers with an 
average  farm  size  of  3.1  ha.  About  81%  of  these  farms  (representing  71,000  farms)  are 
smallholder farmers owning less than 5 ha. Households headed by women make up about 1% of 
the households.40 Women perform multiple tasks in the household and in agriculture- and 
livestock-related activities. They are responsible for all domestic work, with limited engagement 
in activities outside of the home. Women are responsible for water collection from hand pumps in 
open communal areas or from irrigation canals. Their main economic activities are livestock 
farming and marketing of dairy products at the village level. Women also contribute to seasonal 
farm activities like transplanting, weeding, and harvesting. The literacy rate among adult women 
is only 22% compared to 58% for men.  About 85% of literate adults are not able to attain a middle 
or high school education because such schools do not exist in villages. Access to social services, 
like hospitals or maternity clinics is difficult for women as the facilities are located in towns. Rural 
areas are served by basic health units.  
 
38.  The project is categorized effective gender mainstreaming. The project activities will 
directly support the improvement of agricultural productivity and income of farmers including the 
poor and women working in the agriculture sector. The project will address these gender issues 
by (i) installing cattle baths, and passage bridges in strategic locations of the irrigation system; 
(ii) improving  women’s  participation  in  the  WUAs;  (iii)  training  women  in  on-farm  water 
management, improved agricultural practices and crop production; and (iv) implementing the 
social development program (para. 14) that will contribute to human development in the project 
area. The project will support upgrading of a girl’s primary school to a middle school, improvement 
of facilities in a basic health unit, and vocational training for 1,000 men and women. It will also

F.  Safeguards 
 
39.  In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the project’s safeguard 
categories are as follows.41 
 
40.  Environment (category A). The draft environmental impact assessment (EIA) which 
contains an environmental management plan was prepared by the PID in accordance with ADB’s 
Safeguard Policy Statement. The first draft of the EIA was disclosed on the ADB website in 
February 2020. The second draft of the EIA, which incorporates the second round of an ecological 
survey, the biodiversity action plan (BAP), and the stakeholders engagement plan, was disclosed 
in September 2021. The project interventions will result in positive impacts including increased 
agricultural production and improved livelihoods of rural poor communities. The project will cause 
large-scale, permanent landscape alteration because of the transformation of the semi-arid area 
to irrigated agricultural lands. The key potential adverse impacts are on rakhs (protected range 
lands).42 The BAP was prepared for conservation management activities to offset impacts and 
losses of biodiversity values in the rakhs because of the construction of irrigation canals. The BAP 
also proposed other details, including institutional strengthening measures of the Forest, Irrigation 
and  Agriculture  departments,  sustainable  agriculture,  and  eco-tourism  potential.  A  tree 
management plan has been prepared for effective implementation of tree plantation along the 
irrigation  canals  which  will  provide  a  wind  barrier.  The  plan  will  also  delineate  roles  and 
responsibilities between various stakeholders for tree planting and maintenance. 
 
41.  The project may induce habitat modification, community fragmentation and increased 
pesticide use. Adequate mitigation measures have been incorporated into the project design and 
addressed in the EIA. These include canal crossings, and farmers’ capacity enhancement in 
appropriate agricultural practices including pesticide management. Other potential environmental 
impacts  will  occur  during  construction,  such  as  noise  and  dust,  which  are  temporary  and 
reversible. Adequate inputs for environmental management plan implementation monitoring have 
been provided for the project management office, and the project management and construction 
supervision consultant. A third-party environmental monitor will also be engaged. Stakeholder 
consultation was undertaken during project preparation. The project stakeholder engagement 
plan was prepared for further enhancement of the stakeholder consultation. The additional 
consultation is being conducted, and will be continued during the project implementation also. A 
grievance redress mechanism will be established. 
 
42.  Involuntary resettlement (category A). About 2,279 ha (5,632 acre) of land (1,488 ha of 
private land and 791 ha of government land) will be required for the right of way of irrigation canals 
of the Choubara branch system under output 1. About 4,686 households (29,628 persons) will be 
affected, of which 35 households will require relocation. In total, 123,186 trees and 1,779 ha 
(4,395 acres) of crops are estimated to be affected. There are estimated 226 affected structures. 
Of the 1,488 ha of privately owned land, about 1,481 ha (99.5%) were acquired during 2008–
2011. This was well in advance of ADB’s discussion on project financing (in 2019). During project 
preparation  (in  2020)  it  was  identified  that  nearly  half  of  the  landowners  had  not  been 
compensated. To address this legacy issue, the PID agreed to the following measures: (i) to

cleaning, and for their kitchen gardens. The construction of cattle baths will enable women to provide their cattle with

roles in livestock production.  
d  The baseline study for the project shows that households headed by women comprise about 1% of all households 
and that 93% of households are farming households engaged in crop production and livestock raising. The Punjab 
Khal Panchayat Act 2019 does not prohibit women farmers from becoming members of the khal panchayat (field 
channel user group) for water users associations. The Punjab Khal Panchayat Authority is mandated to have at least 
two female members.

metadata.Subject:
The project will contribute to enhancing food security and rural economic growth in Punjab province. It will increase the agricultural production and productivity of the project area by developing a new irrigation system. The Greater Thal Canal (GTC) irrigation scheme will convert 704,000 hectares (ha) of low productive barani (rain-fed) lands in Bhakkar, Jhang, Muzaffargarh, Khushab, and Layyah districts of Punjab to irrigated and productive lands.

The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.

This document dated November 2021 is provided for the ADB project 49372-002 in Pakistan.
